title: South Carolina restaurant apologizes for ‘minorities’ help wanted
text:
South Carolina restaurant apologizes for ‘minorities’ help wanted sign South Carolina restaurant apologizes for ‘minorities’ help wanted A sign posted at Kenny's Home Cooking in Spartanburg, South Carolina included the phrase "Minorities need not apply." (WYFF) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS   10:20 PM 
A controversial sign that appeared to single out minorities at a South Carolina restaurant has been causing business issues for its owners. 
The “help wanted” sign at Kenny’s Home Cooking in Spartanburg read, “Minorities need not apply” in both Spanish and English at the bottom. 
Owner Sook Shin said the incident was a misunderstanding and her intentions were not to offend customers. 
Shin is Japanese and her husband, who is Korean, bought the sign on eBay. She told WYFF-TV that English is not her first language she didn’t fully understand the writing. 
"I never ever meant that, so I'm really sorry. Please forgive me," Shin said. In Spartanburg SC in 2017 Kenny's Home Cooking Restaurant help wanted sign states minorities need not apply! pic.twitter.com/VWQBrluc0z — CoCola721 (@Cocola721) January 29, 2017 
Angry customers took to social media to share photos of the sign over the weekend. Some vowed to report it to federal law enforcement and others swore never to return at the eatery again. 
Melonie Henderson, a server at the restaurant, said the business caters to different nationalities and their staff consists of some minorities. 
"They thought it meant minors, not minorities," Henderson said. 
The owners immediately took down the sign and replaced it with an apologetic one that read: “Dear Customers. I am the owner Sue. I am really sorry for the sign that posted (earlier). I didn’t know what it meant. After I know, I took it off immediately. English is not my first language. And I never thought about it again. I sincerely apologize for (everything).” Kenny’s Home Cooking in Spartanburg, South Carolina. (Google Maps Street View) 
Restaurant employees say the controversy continues to affect business. 
“If we don't have customers, we don't make that much. We rely on our tips,” said server, Deborah Bright.
